` Google Scholar ORCID`{=html}
## Working papers
  • Liberalization–closure cycles in authoritarian regimes: Evidence from contemporary Ethiopia
    W Ayenew, A Kotsadam, JF Tellez
    (2026)
    Summary

    Leadership transitions in authoritarian regimes often follow a liberalization–closure cycle: brief periods of civic opening and inclusion that give way to repression and exclusion. We show that these cycles reshape mass politics through two mechanisms. First, changes in civic space alter the risks and rewards of participation, mobilizing citizens when space opens and demobilizing them when it closes. Second, leadership turnover signals shifts in the relative status of ethnic groups, producing winners who mobilize and losers who demobilize. A further implication is that pro-regime mass organizations, which often rely on coercion and identitarian membership, are especially vulnerable: they weaken when openings reduce coercive pressure and leadership turnover delegitimizes them. We test these arguments with rare, long-running panel data on women’s political engagement under authoritarian rule in Ethiopia (2016–2021), capturing both ordinary citizens and members of regime-linked mass organizations. Our results show how leadership transitions redistribute mass participation in authoritarian systems.

  • Two dilemmas in the politics of ethnic federalism: Experimental evidence from Ethiopia
    B Davis, D Dow, J Springman, JF Tellez
    (2025)
    Summary

    Ethnic federalism creates two dilemmas: what about minorities stuck in the "wrong" state, and which powers should the center versus states control? Surveying Ethiopian students, we find people mostly don't change their minds about ethnic federalism based on power arrangements, except the politically intolerant, who care a lot

  • Interstate Competition and Transnational Threats: How Networks of Nonstate Actors Increase Conflict between States
    B Kinne, JF Tellez, A Stewart, I Iliev, B Derr, S Murthy, P Bernhard
    (2024)
    Summary

    Governments support foreign militias, rebels, and terrorist groups to extend their power, but these transnational networks make interstate tensions worse

  • Ties that bind: the influence of wartime social networks on ex-combatant reintegration
    JF Tellez, M Villamizar-Chaparro
    (2024)
    Summary

    Wartime bonds between fighters are usually seen as pulling ex-combatants back into violence or crime, but we find the opposite among demobilized Colombian fighters actively trying to reintegrate. Using surveys and interviews from a reintegration program, we show these ex-combatants actually discount advice from former fighters

  • Fostering civic engagement in polarized, autocratic regimes: Evidence from a field experiment in Ethiopia
    S Adamu, D Dow, F Hailu, M Mengsteab, J Springman, JF Tellez
    (2024)
    Summary

    Programs that boost civic participation work even in polarized autocracies like Ethiopia, increasing youth engagement without making polarization worse. But some new participation gets channeled toward sectarian causes

  • The media and polarization over historical memory
    L Balcells, JF Tellez, F Villamil
    (2024)
    Summary

    Historical memory issues are highly polarized in Spain, and people's views on how to memorialize the past are resistant to persuasion. Surprisingly, our replication muddies whether these attitudes are uniquely hard to shift

## Peer-reviewed
  • Economic subversion in civil wars: Evidence from the Colombian armed conflict
    H Liu, A Stewart, JF Tellez
    International Studies Quarterly (2025)
    Summary

    Rebels target economically valuable areas to disrupt "business as usual" and impose costs on the state—we call this economic subversion and show it includes looting, sabotage, and related tactics

  • Who should benefit from group-based quotas? Experimental evidence from Brazil
    A Joseph, N Sediqe, JF Tellez
    Journal of Politics in Latin America (2025)
    Summary

    Brazilians care most about economic class and merit when deciding who should benefit from university race quotas, but race still matters

  • Social Cohesion, Economic Security, and Forced Displacement in the Long-Run
    JF Tellez, L Balcells
    Journal of Conflict Resolution (2024)
    Summary

    Displaced Colombians are still economically worse off a decade later, but have more social cohesion than similar people who weren't displaced. We expore why some can return home while others can't

  • The Wars of Others: The Effect of the Russian Invasion of Ukraine on Spanish Nationalism
    L Balcells, JF Tellez, F Villamil
    The Journal of Politics (2024)
    Summary

    Using a natural experiment, we show that other countries' wars can reshape domestic politics in unexpected ways

  • Forced displacement, social cohesion, and the state: Evidence from eight new studies
    E Myers, A Sacks, JF Tellez, E Wibbels
    World Development (2024)
    Summary

    This special issue synthesizes nine new studies covering 30+ countries on how displacement affects social cohesion among refugees and host communities

  • State Absence, Vengeance, and the Logic of Vigilantism in Guatemala
    DA Dow, G Levy, D Romero, JF Tellez
    Comparative Political Studies (2023)
    Summary

    Guatemalans prefer vigilante justice when crimes are especially transgressive and the state won't prosecute, but their preferences also depend on who the victim and perpetrator are. Using a survey experiment with 9,000 households, we find that vigilantism isn't just about state absence

  • Taking dyads seriously
    S Minhas, C Dorff, MB Gallop, M Foster, H Liu, JF Tellez, MD Ward
    Political Science Research and Methods (2021)
    Summary

    Introduce and motivate AME model for dyadic network data

  • Land, Opportunism, and Displacement in Civil Wars: Evidence from Colombia
    JF Tellez
    American Political Science Review (2021)
    Summary

    Armed groups don't just displace people for war-strategic reasons. Local actors can also use the chaos of war to pursue private interests

  • Peace without Impunity: Worldview in the Settlement of Civil Wars
    JF Tellez
    The Journal of Politics (2021)
    Summary

    People's core values shape what kind of peace deals they'll accept, with authoritarians demanding harsher punishment for combatants. Using survey experiments during Colombia's peace process, I find these fundamental differences in worldview help explain why publics split on peace deals, and why many authoritarian types just sat out the referendum entirely.

  • Who wants peace? predicting civilian preferences in conflict negotiations
    AM Montoya, JF Tellez
    Journal of Politics in Latin America (2020)
    Summary

    Using machine learning on 12 years of Colombian survey data, we identify what actually predicts whether people support peace talks with FARC

  • Repression and dissent in contemporary Catalonia
    L Balcells, S Dorsey, JF Tellez
    British Journal of Political Science (2020)
    Summary

    Spain's 2017 crackdown on Catalonia's independence referendum backfired: it temporarily increased public support for independence and anger at the Spanish state.

  • Local Order, Policing, and Bribes: Evidence from India
    JF Tellez, E Wibbels, A Krishna
    World Politics (2020)
    Summary

    Policing quality varies wildly even within cities. We show it depends on how well-connected people and neighborhoods are, using surveys from 8,000 households across 160 Indian slums

  • Hierarchy and the Provision of Order in International Politics
    K Beardsley, H Liu, PJ Mucha, DA Siegel, JF Tellez
    The Journal of Politics (2020)
    Summary

    The international system isn't anarchic, it's structured by trade communities where powerful states use their position to impose order

  • Peace agreement design and public support for peace: Evidence from Colombia
    JF Tellez
    Journal of Peace Research (2019)
    Summary

    Colombians cared a lot about specific provisions in the peace deal with FARC, not just whether there was peace or war

  • The rise of the Islamic State and changing patterns of cooperation in the Middle East
    JF Tellez, J Roberts
    International Interactions (2019)
    Summary

    When ISIS emerged, it didn't just threaten individual states—it rewired the entire network of Middle Eastern diplomacy, pushing major powers to cooperate while isolating frontline states.

  • Worlds Apart: Conflict Exposure and Preferences for Peace
    JF Tellez
    Journal of Conflict Resolution (2019)
    Summary

    Colombians in conflict zones are more supportive of peace deal but less willing to coexist with former fighters

## Other writing Book chapters, reports, blogs...
  • Entre el plomo y la pluma: apoyo ciudadano a las negociaciones de paz 2004-2015
    AM Montoya, JF Téllez
    Paz y opinion publica en Colombia (2024)
  • Social Cohesion and Forced Displacement : A Synthesis of New Research.
    World Bank (2023)
  • The Effect of Social Ties on Engagement & Cohesion: Evidence from Ethiopian University Students
    USAID (2023)
  • Las guerras de los otros: ¿cómo nos afectan políticamente?
    El Diario (2023)
  • El impacto de la deportacion.
    Revista Actualidad Politica (2022)
  • Biden wants to halt deportations. Here’s what happens when migrants are sent back.
    The Monkey Cage at the Washington Post (2021)
  • 4 things the Biden administration should pay attention to with the border crisis
    The Brookings Institution (2021)
  • Encuesta a deportados: Solo quieren volver a huir del país. Plaza Pública’.
    Plaza Pública’ (2021)
  • Five years after Colombia’s peace deal, the FARC is no longer on U.S. terrorist group lists
    The Monkey Cage at the Washington Post (2021)
  • Freedom House’s scarlet letter: Assessment power through transnational pressure
    J Roberts, JF Tellez
    The power of global performance indicators (2020)
  • Indonesia’s Generasi Program Long-term Impact Evaluation Report
    World Bank (2018)
  • Mid-Term Performance Evaluation of the Land and Rural Development Program
    USAID (2017)
